channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: After 7 Months, British Hacking Trial Heads to Jury
item.description: Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson — tabloid editors and former lovers — are accused of condoning the intercepting of voice mails and other practices.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Finally, a Pollution Index Beijing Can Love
item.description: A new survey seeks to gauge how open officials are about levels of pollution at the sources of the problem.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: About 66,000 pounds of dead fish were cleared from the Fuhe River in Wuhan, Hubei Province, last fall after the water was polluted with ammonia.

item.title: ‘Friendly Fire’ Strike Kills 5 Special Operations Soldiers in Afghanistan
item.description: The Americans and at least one Afghan soldier were killed when a coalition aircraft accidentally struck their position, Afghan and American officials said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Ukraine Plans to Open Corridors for Civilians to Flee Violence in East
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko offered aid to those displaced by the fighting as talks with Russia have so far failed to broker a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
item.description: Soldiers abandoned Iraq’s second-largest city as fighters raided military bases and the governor’s building.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By SUADAD AL-SALHY and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: A Kurdish security officer stood guard as families fleeing the violence in the Iraqi city of Mosul waited at a checkpoint near Arbil, in Iraqi Kurdistan.

item.title: India Ink: Police Statements Cloud Alleged Rape and Murder Case, Analysts Say
item.description: Police reform advocates have criticized the contradictory police statements about the alleged rape of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh in May.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard on May 31 near a tree where the bodies of two girls were found hanging in Badaun district in Uttar Pradesh on May 31.

item.title: Israeli Parliament Elects Rivlin as New President
item.description: The selection of Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician, ends what was seen as an unseemly race for a largely ceremonial post.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician and former Parliament speaker, center, shook hands with the former minister Meir Shitrit at the Knesset in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: High-Profile Conference to Draw Attention to Sexual Violence in War
item.description: The initiative has drawn support from the movie star Angelina Jolie, Secretary of State John Kerry and the British foreign secretary William Hague.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Arm Syria’s Opposition
item.description: American interests demand that we support the moderate fighters against both Assad and the jihadists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT S. FORD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Support for Blind University Aspirant Turns to Censure
item.description: When Li Jinsheng became among the first Chinese blind people to take the regular university entrance examination, he made history. Now he says he failed, and he’s being pilloried.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Li Jinsheng at his massage center in Zhumadian, Henan Province.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Making Naughty in the New India
item.description: The state has many legitimate roles. Regulating sex is not one of them.
item.dc:creator: By SIDDHARTH DHANVANT SHANGHVI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Artful Dodgers of Brazil
item.description: How an exuberant style of soccer play helped to unify a troubled nation.
item.dc:creator: By OLIVIER GUEZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Clerical Rule, Luxury Lifestyle
item.description: Much of Iran’s wealth is in the hands of government officials and their cronies.
item.dc:creator: By SHAHRZAD ELGHANAYAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A New Map, Defined by Gas
item.description: America’s shale gas could increase the power of U.S. manufacturing and challenge Russia’s reach.
item.dc:creator: By VALI R. NASR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Despite Critics, China Asserts Democratic Progress in Hong Kong
item.description: As tensions mount in Hong Kong, the Chinese government lays out its argument for how Hong Kong has gotten better under its rule.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Insurgents Attack Pakistani Airport Again Amid Military Raids
item.description: A heated gun battle was the second attack on the airport in two days. And the death toll from Sunday’s attack rose to at least 36 as at least seven charred bodies were recovered from a cold-storage area.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Security forces checked a motorbike near an airport training facility in Karachi that was attacked on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Urges Greater Innovation in ‘Core Technologies’
item.description: Delivering his biggest speech on science and technology, President Xi Jinping demands that China master and control the new technologies that, he said, will decide global economic and political winners and losers.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: An employee working at a production line in a Geely automotive manufacturing plant in Ningbo, China.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Complains About Plutonium in Japan
item.description: China has complained that Japan has 640 kilograms of plutonium that it has not reported to the International Atomic Energy Agency.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Nuclear fuel rods in the spent fuel pool in the building housing the No. 4 reactor at Tokyo Electric Power's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in November 2013.

item.title: For Western Oil Companies, Expanding in Russia Is a Dance Around Sanctions
item.description: BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and other big Western oil companies are striking deals and plowing money into Russia even as more sanctions loom.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Oil storage tanks in Siberia. Exxon Mobil and Rosneft are joining to explore the nearby Bazhenov shale formation.

item.title: In Britain, School Report Cites Division Over Islam
item.description: An inquiry found a culture of “fear and intimidation” of staff members and blamed fundamentalist Islamic school board governors.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Peres, at 90, Is Ready to Leave the Israeli Presidency, but Not to Retire
item.description: The sole survivor of Israel’s founding generation in public office, Shimon Peres stretched the bounds of a largely ceremonial office.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Shimon Peres of Israel during a prayer at the Vatican, where he met with Pope Francis and the Palestinian leader.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Court Rejects Disputed Vote to Replace Interim Prime Minister
item.description: Libya’s top court rejected the Islamist-led Parliament’s appointment of a new prime minister in a contested vote.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Vice President in Court for Questioning in Corruption Case
item.description: A simmering political scandal took a dramatic turn when a judge forced Vice President Amado Boudou to appear in a Buenos Aires court to answer questions.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: At Least 40 Die in Attacks
item.description: Two explosions near the offices of Kurdish political parties were the deadliest of attacks that killed at least 40 people in northern Iraq, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: General Has Hopeful View About the Nuclear Talks With Iran
item.description: As Iran and the United States began talks in Geneva to advance negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear activities, a top Israeli intelligence official said he believed that Iran was serious about ensuring the success of the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
